channel.title: My first thing in BrainFuck
channel.description:
[code] ++++++++++ [>+++++++>++++++++++<<-] >++. >+++++. [/code]
Now, I'm going to explain this some.
The first line, sets array[0] equal to 10, so that the loop will loop 10 times.
The second line, each loop adds 7 to array[1] and 10 to array[2], and minuses 1 from array[0], hence why it loops 10 times, the main reason we want this, is because in the end, array[1] = 70 and array[2] = 100 this is because 70 is near the ASCII code for H and 100 is near the ASCII code for i
The third line, this moves to array[1] where we have the 70 stored, increments it by 2, so we get the ASCII code for H (72) and the '.' prints it out.
The last line, this line moves to array[2] where we have 100 stored, then increments it by 5, so we get the ASCII code for i (105) and the '.' prints it out.
I hope this helped someone interested a little in BrainFuck lol, I find it kindof fun :D
In the end, it prints out 'Hi'

item.title: My first thing in BrainFuck
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

++++++++++                            
[>+++++++>++++++++++<<-]    
>++.
>+++++.

Now, I’m going to explain this some.

The first line, sets array[0] equal to 10, so that the loop will loop 10 times.

The second line, each loop adds 7 to array[1] and 10 to array[2], and minuses 1 from array[0], hence why it loops 10 times, the main reason we want this, is because in the end, array[1] = 70 and array[2] = 100 this is because 70 is near the ASCII code for H and 100 is near the ASCII code for i

The third line, this moves to array[1] where we have the 70 stored, increments it by 2, so we get the ASCII code for H (72) and the ‘.’ prints it out.

The last line, this line moves to array[2] where we have 100 stored, then increments it by 5, so we get the ASCII code for i (105) and the ‘.’ prints it out.

I hope this helped someone interested a little in BrainFuck lol, I find it kindof fun

In the end, it prints out ‘Hi’
